In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function to wrap strings by iterating over the words and adding a new line when the text width limit is reached. Here's how you can define such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(text)
        if length(word) + sum(length, lines) > text_width
            push!(lines, "")
        end
        push!(lines, word)
    end
    return join(lines; separator="\n")
end
```

This function uses `split` to break the text into a list of words. It then iterates over these words and checks if adding the current word to the total length of the line would exceed the specified `text_width`. If so, it adds an empty string to the `lines` array to start a new line. Finally, it joins the lines back together using "\n" as the separator to create a multi-line string.

You can call this function with some text and specify the maximum width you want:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line.")
"Hello there!\nThis is a very long\nsentence that should be\nwrapped at 10 characters\nper line."
```

In this example, the text is wrapped at around 10 characters per line as requested.
